values:
Home friends!!

Hi! Wow, it's been forever. To all of you whom I haven't spoken to in FOREVER, I'm really super sorry, but things have calmed down so I think I have more time to stay in touch. Just know that everytime I hear from you I smile all over. 
Vassar is awesome. I love it here. Love the classes, love the people. My roommate rocks. I've been in two shows thus far and am rehearsing for a third. The first, the Cherry Orchard, was an absolute catastrophe. Creepy, terrible director. Cool cast though, so I'm glad I met them even though Chekhov is definitely turning in his grave at about 1,000 revolutions per minute. 
Then directors workshops, a much better experience.
And now, Much Ado About Nothing! Yay! I'm playing Hero! Yay! I'm super excited! Yay!
Oh, and there's so much more I can't even begin to think about let alone write. In short, I'm very happy and I love all of you and hope you're all doing marvelously.

Love,Me

Today we had our first clowning class. It was absolutely horrific. I had heard of the Ring of Fire before, and I knew what it was, but never in my wildest imaginings could I ever have concieved how bad it really is. Here's what you do: the class forms a circle of chairs, and one by one each actor enters the circle. That actor can do whatever he/she wants, but cannot leave the circle until he/she makes the entire circle laugh at the same time. Or until two minutes are up. Sweet Jesus. We all failed miserably, and yet I still cannot believe how badly it makes me feel. The point is to learn where failure lives in your body, how you react to it because apparently, clowns live in failure. The rest of the class was actually really really fun. We played games and were silly and got beat on the head with a stick and threw balls around. Stuff like that. But I can't get the Ring of Fire out of my head. I want to try it again. It's sadistic, really.
Other than that I've been great. Eating lots of icecream, hanging out with Ned and the kids here, being a starfish, learning about my "shakras." My scene is turning out to be super-fun. Hooray for Shakespeare! Love to all.

I am feeling so so so much better thanks to some sleep and some new friends. Friends are great, I love friends. I especially love you guys. Thanks so much for the encouragement, it makes me feel ten times better. Oh, and guess what? We were assigned scenes a couple of days ago and I'm doing the Miranda/Ferdinand Logge-man Tempest scene with this cool cat Casey! Coincidence? I think not! Well, I suppose it is...Anyway, it's very exciting. We've done dropping in (very intense: scene partners sitting in each other's faces with two teachers whispering in their ear these questions after every single word. Example: "O. What do you want to say to him? O. Do you want to have sex with him? O. Is the blood rising in your cheeks? O. What would he look like naked? Father. Do you love your father? Father. Do you hate your father? Father. Is your father growing old? Father. Will he die soon? Father. Will that leave you all alone?" and on and on like that for an hour and a half staring into your scene partners eyes. And that was only half the scene. So in total it took three hours just do to that small amount of text.) And then standing up, which is the same but...well...standing up. And tonight we do our first text work. Hooray! Work!

I'm fucking tired. I'm tired of this. I'm tired of all these new people, baring my soul every fifteen minutes, the highs and lows that come with this place. It's like Mountain School all over again, and we all know how good that was for me. On the one hand, I feel that I'm growing as a person. Hopefully after all this fucking opening up I'll be less of a shy person and more stable in my self. But for now, I can't wait to get out. Which, I suppose, is why we have a break on Monday. Oh my god, I need it so badly. I just need some time out. I need some sleep, some time to be in my comfort level, not to be scanning my life for horrific incidents and then telling people about them. I just need some familiarity. A song, a face. I miss you guys a lot. I will have so much to tell you after this is over.

So I'm beginning to breathe through my ass. No joke. Through my ass. Every time I take a breath now (when I relax), I feel my sphincter muscle let go like I'm about to take a poo. IT FEELS GREAT! And it's a major breakthrough for me. Yay! And today in voice, when I breathed out, I could feel my whole body jiggle like a wave of jelly. So fucking cool. So I'm making blissful progress. I named my voice Sally. 

Some of this stuff is terrifying. Like today we had to do this whole thing in front of everybody and one of the questions was "what I don't want to tell you is..." and it was absolutely fucking the scariest thing I've ever done but it was wierd because instead of having a breakdown, I had this complete high of joy that lasted for like ten minutes.

Did you know that, according to a scientific study, the stress a trained, experienced professional actor goes through as he/she steps on stage is equivalent to a car crash? Crazy.

Mmm...I just went for a lovely run. It's twenty to breakfast, and then I have a hunch we'll be doing voice again this morning and Basics I this afternoon and seeing As You Like It tonight. That would be a good schedule. Basics I rocks. We're split into two groups with three teachers per group and while none of the teachers are like Jonathan Epstein, they make you feel much more comfortable. So, you cry less because they're scary and more because they're kind. It's good. A very good vibe. I haven't worked my piece yet, but I'm looking forward to it. We did them all at the beginning though, so most of my jitters are gone. That's all I really have to say. I'm hungry.

So I'm beginning to realize that the reason I knew nothing about the program before I came is not a lack of communication, it's a theory. It's a practice, a lesson. We only know what we're doing about half an hour before we do it. As in, we'll wake up to find our morning class posted, go to lunch to find our afternoon class posted, and go to dinner to find our evening class posted. They think this will keep our head in the lesson and away from "oh god, I have to do my monologue tonight." And it works. Yesterday we did an exercize as the teachers watched with these big terrible black binders filled with all our headshots, resumes, essays, and god knows what else. It was one of those let's be five, let's be twelve, let's be thirteen things so basically not only do they know your face, they know everything about your growing up. They see you as a shy five-year-old, an awkward thirteen-year-old. It's scary to let people into all of that, especially when most of us (going to college especially) want to move past it. And yes, of course, I am the youngest here. Most people will be seniors in college or have already graduated. There's one girl who will be a sophomore. This is also fucking scary as hell, but they're nice and kind to me and funny and some of them know my secret: that I'm not actually in college yet. It's wierd to talk about my "school" and then realize that they think I mean Vassar. It's also really cool that most of them mistook me for heading into my senior year at college. This morning we did a beginning vocal exercize with this amazing man named Antonio and a little movement to accompany it with a woman named Kate. I almost threw up and fainted at the same time. Oh my god, I felt so sick. And I went up to Antonio and was like "what the hell should I do? What's going on?" and he told me that it's because my body's not used to so much oxygen and that I should go ahead and throw up on the floor or faint because people will catch me and clean it up. I dunno, but I might take him up on that. I mean, if that's what he wants me to do...I might feel better. So yeah, basically I feel like I've lived my whole five weeks in this one day. I can't can't CAN'T believe how much we're going to accomplish in the next several weeks. Crazy. IT'S CRAZY. And fucking difficult as hell.

Here's my sonnet (let's see if I can do it from memory...)

15

When I consider every living thing
Holds in perfection but a little moment,
That this huge stage presenteth naught but shows
Whereon the stars in secret influence comment;
When I percieve that men as plants increase,
Cheered and check'd even by the self-same sky,
Vaunt in their youthful sap, at height decrease,
And wear their brave state out of memory;
Then the conceit of this inconstant stay
Sets you most rich in youth before my sight,
Where wasteful Time debateth with Decay,
To turn your day of youth to sullied night;
And all at war with Time for love of you,
As he takes from you, I engraft you new.

WOOHOO!!

Arg, I'm trying so hard to pack...but I just can't! I keep thinking...oh, but I want all my laundry to be done or oh, but I'm going to have to brush my teeth in the next three days, so I can't pack any of that stuff now. I hate packing. Hate it. Well, at least I know there's a drug mart near the campus so I can buy toothpaste or whatever if I leave it behind. Oh my god I can't even handle the suspense anymore. I can't believe it's so close. SO CLOSE. Hooray for meeting dorks like me! I should really get on the material I need to know...I'm thinking that fucking awful Juliet monologue, the one where she drinks the poison? It scares the crap out of me so I feel like I should do it. And I have to pick a new sonnet. It's my excuse to learn new material.

Ooh! and I finished my silk painting. It's kinda neat except there's a big black blotch in the corner. I just have to set it and then I'm done! Hooray!

Saw Hannah and Sean last night in the Tempest. Everyone should go see it! It's tempestuous! And Hannah and Sean are great, as always. And of course Mr. Hawkes. Free Shakespeare. Outside. What's not to love?

It's sonnet time with Alex and Leah...

Today I am trying my hand at silk painting. I haven't really started yet, but I have my cloth all stretched out and I have a design in mind. The likelyhood that I'll ever finish it is probably about 1% but it'll be fun anyway, right?
The last few days have been pretty relaxing. Preparing for college and Shakespeare, things of that nature. I'm really bummed that things didn't work out yesterday because of a stupid doctor's appointment. The best part is, he doesn't know what I have either. He made certain... implications and then said "yeah, I don't really know. Take these and hope it clears up." They're fucking horse pills is what they are. Well, at least it's not strep.
Oh, and I watched Topsy-Turvy with my dad yesterday. It's about Gilbert and Sullivan, and it's alright (Jim Broadbent's a genius) but the crowning moment was when Andy Serkis made an appearance as a choreographer. Mmm...Gollum so sexy.

Hello everybody!
Does anybody else experience a really strange feeling in the summer? It's like thirst, but it can't be quenched. It's like pining for something similar to water, but when you drink a glass of water, it doesn't go away. It never goes away. The feeling is especially prevalent while wearing a bathing suit. Am I just weird? Somebody tell me they feel the same way! It's like homesickness...but I'm home. I love it and hate it at the same time.
Anyhow. Summer's great. I've been reading a lot. I just finished The Hours which I highly recommend even if you didn't like the movie because I didn't like the movie, but this book is astounding, especially if you've read Mrs. Dalloway. And I've started Kissing in Manhattan (cheers, Maddie!) by David Schickler who is amazing. It's very G. G. Marquez meets David Sedaris. Eh. Kind of. And hanging out with people. You know how you do. 
Oh, and I cut my hair really short. It's fun and kind of poofy but in a way I'm okay with.
Hurrah!

So....I'm not actually in Scotland yet. Yesterday we got to the airport and checked in right behind some soccar-playing junior whose name I had for a second and then lost again. And our flight was delayed because of summer storms on the east coast. And delayed again. And delayed again until finally we missed our flight from Newark to Glasgow. Big bummer. So we're trying again today. This time we got an earlier flight to Newark in hopes that even if it is delayed, we'll still make our connecting flight. The sad part is, even though I had an extra day at home, there was nothing I could do with it! So sad. Well, here we go again...

These last several days have been fantastic! I love my friends! Working on the farm, riding bikes, seeing movies, what else could I ask? And now it's Thursday morning, the date of my departure. We leave at 1:00pm, so unfortunately I left all my packing to the last minute. I hate packing. It's very stressful because I'm always afraid I'll forget something and then be miserable. Like pants. What if I forget to bring any pants?? I'm very excited about the trip, and kind of nervous but I think it'll be really fun. However, I will really miss everybody!! I'm back the 29th. Take care until then! Love, me.

AHHH!! That was so much fun! Sorry guys, this is really long and boring and I can't figure out how to make it a neat little link like on Maddie's but it makes you feel so accomplished. And there are things I NEVER thought anybody else would know about, like the Far Pavilions and The Gospel According to Biff!! AH! So many memories! How great. AND THE WESTING GAME! FUN!

Hi guys! It's been an uber-long time. Let's see...what's new...I'm still working every day in the glorious sunshine. I'm all nice and dirty and I have primer all over me because I've been working on the farm stand. Ooh, I've been doing some timberframing. I definitely didn't expect to do that ever again. And hanging out with people and seeing a lot of movies at the Latchis Theater. It's the coolest movie theater ever. Tickets for five bucks and candy for two and it's this beautiful art deco building with fountains and tile and murals of romantic French countrysides and pillars and balconies all over. Not fancy, just old school. Two of my friends work there so we go and hang out. It's the best job ever. They have a rush and then they hang out for two hours and eat candy. It's just like Empire Records: a bunch of friends hanging out, watching movies for free, playing cards, and no boss (well, there is one in Empire Records, but he's cool so he doesn't count). And apparently there's this guy who's a lot like Lucas!! Eek! Anyhow, I saw Van Heilsing last night. It was a fun movie. Think James Bond/Indiana Jones except not quite as clever but at least it tries. Oh, and Richard Roxburgh plays Dracula (Duke from Moulin Rouge)!!!! Oh, and this other guy plays the sidekick (Faramir from LOTR. And not only that, I just found out he plays Audrey in Moulin Rouge as well!! You know, at the very beginning, the cross-dressing playwright who leaves because he's jealous of Ewan McG?? Ahh! I love it!) I spent the whole movie alternately thinking to myself "who IS that? What have I seen him in??/ When did Kate Beckinsale become such a fox? What happened to her Hero persona??" Um so yeah, this is way too long. But I'm having fun and working hard and eating good food and missing all of you guys tons! BUCKETS!

Hey guys!
I'm on the farm. Ahh...It feels so good. Dirt. Everywhere. Kids. Plants. It's really, really cold, but so sunny you hardly notice. Very beautiful. We transplanted a lot of stuff today, both into bigger seedling trays and the field. Dirt under fingernails. Gritty. Soft. Moist (love that word, to all who hate it). My sister and I stayed up talking late last night and so now I'm tired. As shown by my extremely poorly written entry. We rocked and put our feet up on the wood stove and looked through her old yearbooks. Bella is quite reasonable now, and Henry is just beginning to talk. They like watching this signlanguage video, and the themesong is stuck in my head like Pooh in the doorway. You know? Yeah, it's time to go to bed.

It's like a fever. I can't eat, can't sleep. All I can think about is working more. I wake up at 5am and find myself thinking about Leer and Cordelia. Yesterday we worked from ten to ten. Basically, we each got up and did one of our monologues and he coached us through, picking out things to prove points he was making, highlighting the antithesis, the ethos (ethics), pathos (passions), logos (logic). Things like that. So I get up, right, and I'm shaking, I'm so scared. Not that I'm terrible by these standards, it's not that. I'm holding my own. It's just that I'm absolutely terrified of him and his opinion of me. He's  a very scary man. 'Intense' doesn't even begin to describe what he is. So I do my monologue, and he says okay, now antithesis etc., like you're serving a tennis ball. And I do, kind of. And he begins to set up the scene. It's a Hermione monologue from the Winter's Tale, and I'm on trial for being unfaithful to my husband, the king. And he says shame. And I think okay, shame is good. Shame is very easy for me. He says just take a moment to begin to understand the shame you feel. Look around. And I do. And I can feel the blood rushing to my face. And he does this thing where he stands just next to you and focuses on you with his entire body and mind and strokes your cheek with his thumb. And it's so gentle. And I'm really into it, right? And so as soon as I begin my monologue, I burst out crying. And I sob my way through half of it. Real tears. I mean, I'm really going at it. And then I get real pissed off and we play with logos, pathos, ethos with the second half of the thing. And he says great, and I sit down. And I'm totally soaked and drained, but god what a feeling.  Holy shit, guys. The man's a fucking genius. So that's my day. The people here are awesome. It's great. Sometimes I forget I'm only eighteen. We go for food, go to the bar at the end of the day. I guess it makes me feel very grown up. And the thing that connects us all is this language, this beautiful language. It truly breaks down boundaries.

Johnny: Even when you do nothing, you create an elliptical antithesis because you're doing what the audience doesn't expect.
Me: What?!
Johnny: Every time you breathe, accept the universe. Accept that what is, is.
Me: What?! How?!
Holy shit. Holy SHIT guys. There's so much to learn. I can't even begin to fathom. We worked three and a half hours yesterday, and I didn't even notice. Once, I took a bathroom break and all I could think was "Hurry UP, Gwen. I need to get back in there." He's even better than I remember. Every time he says a bit of text, I fall in love for a second. He's captivating. And has two sons....Well, nevermind that. One's named Tiger :). The dorms here are alright. Well, pieces of shit. But I don't even notice them. It's like the text creates this lovely plush environment that I can walk around in without caring about my surroundings. Which is exactly opposite his point. I know, I know, ground the text in reality. But maybe what I mean is that the text makes reality seem more important, more beautiful. God, if that could happen to everyone? There would be no war. We'd all be scholars. Ten more hours today. Holy shit guys. I'm in love with a dead man. Fuckin' A. 
Love you all.

I'm done with highschool! I can hardly believe it! It's like that feeling after you're done with finals and you realize that all of summer stretches ahead of you!!
Tomorrow I'll be in Lennox working my butt off. I just hope I'm not entirely blown out of the water by some of these people. I hope they're gentle. I hope they won't hate me for ruining their workshop. I have my monologues and scene down pretty well. Man, it's time to work again. I'm ready. Bring it on.
For those of you who are curious, here's where I'll be and what I'll be doing:
Tomorrow: Leave
Monday: Reside at 264 Ames Hill Rd.
Brattleboro, VT 05301
May 23: I'm back!!
I probably won't be online often. Ever. The computer there is really more of a coffee-cup holder. But you will all be in my hearts (as you always are!), and I'll do my best to write postcards. I love you all! And I'll see you in three weeks!!

Just got home from the icecream shop. Covered in fudge, strawberry sauce etc. Very sticky. We got in new peach-flavored icecream!! Everybody should try it, it's truly excellent (coming by a peach fan like myself. I don't know what it is about them. I like how they're fuzzy and orange. Like a linty sunset.)Meez and I worked for the first time together and you'll never guess who came in. CHRIS CASSINIDY!!!! ahhh!! I wouldn't even have recognized him, but Meezie said "oh my god, that's Christ Cassinidi!" He didn't recognize either of us, so it was a little awkward. Felt sort of like a stalker. Welcome to my life. AND the best friend of a girl I grew up with who then moved to Pittsburg and then Kansas. Coincidence? I think not. It felt kind of like a huge finale at the end of a play, like my childhood is being swept up into song and dance. Like suave men in tapshoes and sequins are about to burst from the freezers and wave their hats at me. To bed, to bed.

Hi guys, I'm here for my bi-monthly entry!!
Basically I'm procrastinating and the spirit moved me so here I am back at my livejournal. Here's what I should be doing now:
Finding a monologue from Shkspr's later works
Reading the Enormous Room (great book!!!)
Doing physics
Doing stat
I'm excited for prom, it's going to be a good time. It makes me nervous, prom. I always have a good time, though, so I don't know why I'm worried.
Can I just say for a minute how much I love Shakespeare? I love him. I do. I could spend the rest of my life devoted to his works. It's so beautiful and so true and so sad and so poignant and so funny but all of his humour is so good because it's SO HEART-WRENCHING. God. Just humour me for a moment.

The course of true love never did run smooth,
But either it was different in blood...
Or else misgraffed, in respect of years...
Or else it stood upon the choice of merit...
Or if there were a sympathy in choice, 
War, death, or sickness did lay siege to it;
Making it momentary as a sound,
Swift as a shadow, short as any dream,
Brief as the lightning in the collied night,
That (in a spleene) unfolds both heaven and earth
And ere a man hath power to say, behold,
The jaws of darkness do devour it up:
So quick bright things come to confusion.


OH MY GOD!! Can you even believe it??

I always forget. And then I think, foolishly, oh, why not. It would help out. It'll be fun. Just one more Saturday of stale bagels and cabbage-smelling cafeterias and people dressed in black skirts and suitcoats, miserable, tired, bored. It can't be that bad, right? WRONG! This past hour has been a memorizing hell. The only thing that keeps me going is the embarrassment that awaits if I don't get the whole thing down word for word. It's so much more difficult to memorize a speech. A dramatic piece, see, has a plot. A line to follow. As does a speech, I suppose, but it's much more obscure and not as linear. Or colloquial (which would make it so much easier to remember). I have one more day to work on this thing. I barely remember how it begins..."I want to take you on a 600 year tour of history." Mistake number one: don't pick a speech which promises to cover 600 years of history. It's a good speech. But bejeez, if I read it one more time I think I'll barf. If all else fails, I'll just segway into "Sermon" by David Mamet, which I suppose is a kind of speech. That'll wake them up. Okay. Back to work.

So Laura pointed out to me the other day that I have absolutely no excuse now that I'm a second semester senior...It's time to begin writing again in my livejournal. This should be fun. 
News news news...I have a new email account. It's gwendi@sbcglobal.net. I believe that is also my IM, but I can't be sure. We're still working out the kinks. Kinky....
But now I am relaxing and stroking my icecream callous. Yes, it's sad. I have an icecream callous. That's all for me. I'm out.

Well, I am breaking my weekly vigil a week early because tomorrow I'm going on a "Magical Mystery Tour" (the title is somewhat dryly humerous) with the history and Latin teachers as my excursion for the Work/Activities period. I have no idea what's going on, but the tour lasts from eight to five, and when I get home I have to pack for solo (and find my compass and maps. Eek!) which we leave for on Sunday. Four days alone...I'm very much looking forward to that. Apparently this week is notorious for mental breakdowns. I'm keeping my head (unless you count the day I got a letter from my dad), but I'm a wee bit stressed what with a spanish quiz, an in-class history essay and a math test today. 

Thank you all for the information, it was much appreciated. Congradulations to Jill and (I doubt you're reading), Sebastian and Fehr and Nate and whoever else is in it. What's the freshman's name? 

There is a paper birch tree outside my window that my roomate Ashley says looks like it has faces in it. She's absolutely right. It looks like there are several pointy-nosed moustached men gazing haughtily into the boys dorm on the left and the woods on the right. When it's warm and our windows are open, we can hear the boys screaming and playing radios and guitars and quoting "Zoolander" (It seems to follow me). And there is a fire-escape out the window by my bed which we can climb onto to talk to them, and "study" between windows. I just have to be careful not to be naked in full view of the entire boys dorm, which is very possible.

Well, now I have to go to science, where we're going on a hike to look at some abandoned beaver dams. I hope you're all well. All my love.

Oh, and P.S. I'll be home on October 11-13. I'd like to see some/all of you!
Will somebody please tell me what the fuck is going on with the play?! I know nothing, and it's driving me insane! Fill me fucking in!

They slide before me, thin and transluscent as fingernails or that layer of skin caught above the safty pin when you push gently it into your fingertip. The smells and the resins are on my hands, my working hands I know could be sliced off in seconds with the instrument I'm using. But I am not afraid, though I was. It's so gentle with the wood, guiding it where it needs to go and when it falls it falls gently with its fellows on the concrete. My arms are warm and capable from sawing. I glide my finger along the cut, so smooth it feels as if it has always been there. The through tenon, the mortise, are my children and the wall beam my progeny. My partner cuts too deep and I am upset, strangely, because it matters. We are cautious not only because it must fit together with the other beams and braces but because the wood lives and breathes with you, is you. Craftsmanship is a powerful thing, as is pride, and as (interestingly enough) is our beam. 

No the Mountain School has not made me sappy about most things, but honestly, I love barn work. There is more to come. I figure I'll write about one small aspect of my life on my weekly foray into the world of technology. Maybe you'll write back to this, since I don't seem to be getting much mail from you guys. I hope you're well. I'm doing most excellently.

Well guys, I'm on my way. The blood of mermaids runs in my veins but once, and I'm going to take advantage of it (Before you watch any other movie, watch Vanya on 42nd Street and you'll understand). Something is brewing, beginning, and I can't wait to get out the door. Take care of yourselves, everyone, and I'll see you in a bit.

We're down to three days left. I talked with some Mountain School alumns and soon-to-be rookies today and it got me even more excited. I love switchig universes. Universes whose walls are thin as softly-cooked egg yolk. I especially love it when the yolk doesn't break. Not that I like changing identities, but rather place in society. Strangely enough, it seems to work that way. I'm sure I'll discover some fissure in my soul I havn't caught my hem on yet. It's so exciting. And now, because I have a tremendous headache, I'm going to leave you to ponder YOUR soul. Just kidding.

I guess I have a lot to ponder.
What's there to ponder, man, the results are in!...Nice comeback!...

What's there to ponder, man, the results are in!...Nice comeback!...

I will never go shopping again. Well, at least now I have everything I could possibly need for school. Probably more. But hey, who does their wash? Certainly not I, at least not on a regular basis. And now, because I have nothing else to say, I will enlighten you by printing a short story from the anthology Micro Fiction:

But What Was Her Name?
by Dawn Raffel

She was born in December in Baraboo or thereabouts- small, still blue, a girl, and, by some trick of oxygen, alive. She lived to marry late. She bore live descendants. 
See her in the pantry, a knife in the hand, a mother of sons, a baster of ribs, of scraps. There is a knot at the throat. There is a vision of something.
The groom wears wool.
The bride grows thick.
She holds her breath.
Years pass.
She is ripping a lining, draining a steampot, simmering blood. She is sinew and elbow, gnarled in a chair. Her feet are red. A man she has raised delivers a slipper. Look at him! he wears the groom's robe.
Her fingerbone will not release the ring.
"Father?" she says.
She sees her breath.
She was white in the bed of her birth. The past had taken hold of her- the heart's last sleight.

Tremendous, huh? God, it tears at my heart.

1. A sardine is not a salted smelt.

2. If you want to appear intelligent, the wrong thing to say is "Nothing is heard but the cricking of chirpets".

3. Hay un gato furioso (o un padre delicioso) en los pantalones de los Tres Avocados Sexiosos.

4. Stephen has a warped sense of time: when he says "30-minute radio interview" he means "7-minute radio spot", and when he says "3-hour tech-thru", he means "8-hour clowning inferno".

5. As a rule, fairies are sexy.

6. The USA could use more casual, impromptu singing.

7. "Gnarly" is not always an endearing word to use. Ditto for "Babe".

8. You can never have too many glowsticks.

9. Taking care of a gummi-bear fetus is hard work (For those of you who are concerned, his name is "the Jesus" [but we call him "Mm", short for Messiah], and though I havn't seen him since he was a wee nugget, I am told he is the size of Lizzy's palm).

10. A good dose of Sexy Chair spices up any monolouge.

11. There is such a thing as too many museums.

12. Oliver Kahn is the best soccar player.

13. German people are very blunt.

14. You can never go wrong with sesame noodles and cranberry-grapefruit juice.

14. Recipe for an instant night of fun: dress up in a nun costume (with a purple boa and red shoes) and go with some friends (male and female) dressed as Catholic school girls to The Dangerous Lives of Alter Boys (Make sure to make the ticket man guess what movie you're going to see).

15. South Pond tastes sweet.

16. "Raving" is not an obscure term for "Musical Theater".

17. Don't ever let anybody near your sinuses if you don't want to be reduced to a blubbering emotional blob.

18. Honeyed Lavender tea is delicious.

19. Every building should have a parlour.

20. Elvis Costello is worthy of heroic status.

21. The movie Ghostworld will make you cry.

22. There is no such thing as too many blueberries.

23. Shakespeare had something going for him.

24. Models don't think for themselves.
    That's not true!
    Yes it is, Derek.
    OK.

More later...

So I'm off like a prom dress!

You know, right before I travel I get this strange empty excited feeling in my stomach. I had it today as I was filling my cup with ice. This was as the biscuits were being devoured, early in the morning (relatively speaking). I absolutely love getting up early in the morning. It reminds me of Vermont (if it's summer, which, fortunately, it is). I felt so alive this morning. Then I feel asleep for two hours in the car going to a guitar lesson and during my brothers lesson. That was refreshing. 

I feel...like I am about to grow ten feet. I still havn't fully realized the fact that I will be traveling tomorrow. I brought lots of reading and music and a journal, because hopefully if I've learned anything this year, it is how to write frequently. Hmmm...we shall see. So I will have a real journal, like with pen and paper. Crazy, I know. Hopefully I'll learn a lot and see a lot of cool stuff. I'm getting excited now. Now that I have to go to sleep, of course. Well, I need to do some last-minute packing.

Take care, everybody. I'll see you in eleven days.

Soo...stuff has happened between then and now. I saw a show of Pat's today. Hehehehe...Intersting show. I don't know if I like it or not, but it made for an intriguing evening. 

Now my internal clock is officially on summer time. Summertime...and the livin' is easy. One of my favorite songs. Anyhow, this means that I stay up until three or four in the morning and wake up at noon. It's nice, except I don't see so much of the sun and I feel kinda unproductive. Even though it's summer and it's supposed to feel that way. So now I'm feeling really bouncy, and I don't know what to do with myself since nothing is open and it's a little dark to go exploring. I'm sure I'll find something. Like being online. The internet is never closed. 

Hey, did you know that the word "avocado" comes from a Native American word meaning "testicle"? Consider yourself informed.

Necessity breeds penises. Just trust me on that one.

And on that note, I will blindfold you and call you llama-man!

Ok, listen up. Here it is. I have it all figured out. So those of you who want to know WILL, and all will be crystal clear.

My Schedule for the Next 6 Months:

June 19th: Leave for Germany
June 30th: Come back from Germany
July 15th: Leave for Vermont/Lithuania
August 16th: Get back from LITHUANIA, back from Vermont maybe a day later.
August 24th: Mountain School begins.
December 14th: Back from Mountain School.

Now you know.

So I ate a piece of my pie...
Drumroll please.
And it was really good! I'm serious! Very limy, kinda tart. Although the graham cracker crust was just crumbs, and fell apart. I am satisfied. Hurrah. And there was much rejoicing. Yay...

My fingers hurt soooooooo badly. Yesterday I thought I had my callouses from cello still, because playing the guitar wasn't hurting as much as I thought it was going to. Well, I woke up and SURPRISE there they were. Welcome, boys. So typing is an issue.

Anyhow, because of the pain and because I don't have that much more to say, I'm going to sign off for now. But before I go, here's a joke for you:

So a man goes into a restaurant, and he asks what the special is, and the waiter tells him,
"Tongue."
And the man says, "Ewwwww...tongue?! That's disgusting. Why would anybody ever eat something that comes from another animals mouth? I mean, that's so unsanitary. Eww, tongue...gross. Just give me three eggs."

Hahahahah. Don't you just love family reunions?

I just saw absolutely the most fantastic movie I have seen in a long time. The Big Kahuna. With Kevin Spacey, and Danny DeVito is absolutely incredible. I mean, I liked both of these actors before, but this takes it to a whole new level. It's based on a play called Hospitality Suite, so it's pretty contained, but it's SO the best acting I have seen in a long long long long time. Wow. And the script kicks so much ass. Why is it I always fall in love with the plays with no women in them? Ugh, guys get all the best parts. SEE THIS MOVIE!

I made a Key Lime Pie today. It's still chilling (the thing takes three frickin' hours). I feel like such a home-ec gal. But yeah, I make pie. Well, now I have. We'll have to see how it turns out. I don't like condensed milk at all, so I won't be able to forget that image while I'm eating it, but hopefully the lime will block the gooey milky taste. Gross. It's also kinda gross because it calls for lime zest (no surprise, right?), but because I used store bought limes (picky picky), which I think look darker than Key Limes, there are all these dark green goobers in the filling. I'm sorry, I'm making it sound gross. I hope it tastes better than it looks. Of course my family will be nice and say it tastes terrific, but these are also the people (ahem...Papa...ahem) who cheat while playing tennis - IN MY FAVOR! 

Be well, everybody.

So today was relative day. It was fun, actually. We chilled, played Cranium, I read out on the lawn. Still Mrs. Dalloway. That book makes me smile randomly. Seriously, it's like laughing at a joke, I can't help it. But now it's moving into more serious territory. My favorite piece for today was how one person "flowered; flowered from vanity, ambition, idealism, passion, loneliness, courage, laziness, the usual seeds", which I think is adolescence in a nutshell.

Anyhow, I don't have much to throw on this table. It was just a quiet, pleasant day. Ever notice how time gets both slower and faster outside of school (or work or whatever). The days go by so individually. Like individual drops of water (Whoa now, that one's never been used), but the minutes and hours themselves-don't really drag-but they kind of...glide like syrup. Really sticky. So that's my observation for today. I know it's not original, but I'm just warming up.

Ceramics have a very mesmerizing and somewhat theraputic effect. When you step out into the sun afterwords your head hurts and you can't erase the image you spent so long on out of your mind. But listening to happy music and feeling the brush slide and CREATE something is well worth the price of admission. I like creating things. 

And then my relatives dropped in like several ten ton anvils. Actually, it's better than I would make it appear. I enjoy talking to my aunt about children's books and to the rest of them about education. There's just so much...catching up. It gets boring. An age old tradition of pinching cheeks and inside jokes I have no part in. But there are brownies...Luckily I have gained ground around my relatives and I feel better about saying things. Before they would make me feel so stupid. But I'm growing, too.

Today was a good day. It began with a visit to Dr. Leslie, the family pediatritian, who was in remarkably good spirits and we talked about tomatoes and Lithuania and I didn't have to get a shot! The rest of the day was incredibly well spent. Oh children, remember the good times. And then David (my brother) had a really cool friend over and we played Cranium (my parents thought it would be a good thing to take to the Mountain School with me, you know, dorm bonding and all that, so they surprised me with a copy). These next few days will be forms forms forms since I got a whole packet of them to send off very soon. I'm sorry this entry isn't terribly exciting. I just found out about a severe loss to my very good friend, and I don't much feel like writing happily, no matter how good the day.

It's finally here! After all the hours of toil and blood sweat and tears and all that bunk, I'm finally free! SUMMER HAS BLOWN IN LIKE A GAIL OF GREEN! I love it! ...and now I don't know what to do with myself. Well, I will soon find somethng. First on the agenda I think is tennis, followed by, I dunno, there are so many possibilities. Hey, did you hear about that guy who fell into the machine at the upholstering factory?
Oh, don't worry. He's fully recovered.
Hahaha. I am soooo funny.

So I'm going to go enjoy the world.

The world is my oyster; sometimes it snaps your fingers when you try to get in it, but after enough prying and broken nails and poking at it with butterknives you finally open it to find a perfect summer day. Today's the day.

Yes! The worst is over! The fever is breaking! It's all downhill from here! I'm making a left onto Easy Street! So now I'm just chillin like a villian, breezing through vocabulary and letting my mind leak out through my ears, since I don't really need it anymore. Except chem, but whatever, I'm crusing. I'm beginning a Virginia Woolf voyage, and so far it is making me very happy. So many exclamation points, and they don't even make it sound sappy! I was crazy after I got home. I was having problems with spatulas and I kept giggling at myself and stabbing my cucumber multiple times with my bread knife. Then my sweatshirt got hungry and ate the knife. Yum yum yum...And then my parents told me I should go get some rest. That might be a very good idea.

81. Why did the new Italian Navy purchase glass bottomed boats?
a. To see the old Italian Navy
b. ha
c. ha
d. ha

Well, here I am, not studying. Again. Whatever. My mind is a delicate equilibrium of facts. One more will send everything I have learned this year crashing into oblivion. ~Smurfettes hair was originally black?!...Whoa! There it all goes...damn...~ 

Suck it up, Gwen. Three days and then it's all over. I mean, how long can three hours really seem? ~Twenty four hours later~ I feel so old. Like I'm in a time warp where I'm the only one moving. I can feel the wrinkles dripping down my skin. ~Twenty four more hours later~ And that's the last problem...and I'm dead. Oh boy. This is no good...

Ahem...anyway. I think I'll be moving along now.

It is a perfectly beautiful day. A horrible, horrible day to be reading about World War II, but there you have it. Luckily I realized that I don't have to study half the stuff I thought I had to, and the rest I have a pretty good grasp on. Yee-haw. 

I realize that my journal entries are unnecessarily detailed. But I guess what I remember about days are fairly specific. And specificity is the soul of wit. If I'm lucky. 

I can't say much about today as of yet, since the day is still practically in the womb (I LOVE that word!). I'm just chillin, smelling summer, and feeling the breeze through my windows and writing this instead of studying. Just a few more days and then I can forget I ever felt this guilt for not studying. Four...more...days...

So today was a wrapping up of things, although it didn't feel it. I still feel like I should be attending school, yet at the same time I'm making plans to experience summer. I feel wonderfully interested. It's the best feeling, being engaged in something. Feeling the desire to go out and explore my potential and to learn more. I just went out to Borders as a study break and bought three books recommended to me by Ms. Thompson: Mrs. Dalloway by Virginia Woolf, A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man by James Joyce, and Swann's Way by Marcel Proust. I hope I can get through these things. No, actually, I will definitely get through these things because I have a mind to. Literature and writing has become for me what acting once was. I need more. It is difficult, however, because this takes a lot more self-discipline, which is something I don't really excel in. I guess I'll have to learn. Yay learning. It's sad because on the one hand I cannot wait to absorb knowledge, but then when I turn around and see my history book, I want to puke. It's an amazingly repellent quality that I'm experiencing. "Oh, give me excess of it so that, surfeiting, the appetite may sicken and then so die." Well, my appetite is definitely dead. History, ho!

Knew that I would, uh....

Mmm...I had a delightful afternoon. I came home and challenged my brother to a game of tennis. So we rode down to the courts, and it's warm and sunny and humid and I LOVE SUMMER and so we begin to warm up. And since he's been playing all spring and I havn't for several months, of course I'm rusty. So he makes this comment like "So Gwen, I see you're having problems with these lobs," and I decide right then and there to whoop his ass. And I tell him so. I can practically see the kids' ears shrivel at the pool next to the courts. We spin, and I win, so I choose the court with less sun and he serves first. Well, unbeknownst to me, his serve has gained a whole lot of speed. So he wins the first set. And now I'm scared, cause see, my brother has never beaten me. Ever. So I set my jaw and focus, and win the thing six to one. Ahh...now I can breathe again. My pride always pulls through. Ugh, sometimes I sicken myself. And then I go home and take a shower, and now my muscles are all warm and tingly and I feel all clean and good and can I just say again that I LOVE SUMMER! I cannot wait to just have the days to go outside and PLAY. Tennis, swimming, bikeriding, just being outside. Of couse I'm thinking of this now when I have to stay inside to study. 

Oh well, life is good. Sweet like the blueberries that hide under leaves until you find them, and can't bear to dump them in the bucket with all the other lowly blueberries, so you pop it in your mouth, sweet but with a hint of bitterness and the knowledge that berries are a passing thing, which reminds you that it's there on your tounge, and it's so quintessentially SUMMER. 

Summer is growing ripe for the picking.

Today is a day is a day is a day. I'm bored and sad because as Jill pointed out to me, this is a preview of what next years Senior Project will be like. It's so quiet. It's not completely desolate, but not quite as entertaining as usual. In a time of constant change, it's hard sometimes to see the loss as anything but part of the growth. But then there are the times when it feels like the treadmill has spit you off the end and then keeps moving on without you. How's that for poetic insight? 

I've finished my Spanish test, and while it wasn't stellar, I'm happy it's over and I can relax. I have no work left this week. Finals? What finals? I'm going to my brother's middle school concert tonight, so that should be a rip-roaring good time. I'll see a lot of people who I will remember as practically having one foot in the grave, and realize that they aren't so old and that in terms of maturity, I am catching up. Those of you who are reading this and dissagree can suck my left buttock. With all this talk of age I feel like the jaws of time are nibbling at my fingers. Maybe I'm catching up to my old men. Finally.

So my excellent friend Alex, hailing from Vermont, tells me that I will NOT in fact be gallivanting about Europe in Shakespearean garb because we are doing "Dream" as a rave. Maybe I'll dye my hair bright green. That would kick some serious left buttock. But knowing me, that won't actually happen. And I took this quiz. What do you think? Is it me?


Which Toe Are You

Hello everybody, and welcome to the Gwen newsletter. The purpose of this thing is mainly to keep any and all of you who are interested tuned in to what all's going on in any of my many future destinations. Right now, it serves as a distraction and a way to proctrastinate and not study for my impending finals. So if you're ever interested in what dear old Gwen is up to, whether it be picking the fleas out of sheep or gallivanting around Europe in Shakespearean garb, you can come here to be informed. Provided I have an internet connection, of course, which may prove difficult in Lithuania, but for the most part I should be ok.
Today you ask? Today was not bad, not bad at all. Mainly I was bouncing my knees and looking at the clock, or else falling asleep. Watching me would me much like watching the Nature Channel, except there was no sex. Other than that I just basked in the humidity and took hanging bodies from the ceiling. Ahh...obscurity is the soul of wit. Anyhow, I think this is a decent beginning to my journal. I've never had a successful journal before, but we shall see if this is the exception. Be well, be merry, go home now.
